dialogue.statement: Hello! How are you feeling today? What's on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
Hey, I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed, honestly. I just got this amazing opportunity I’ve been dreaming of, but instead of feeling happy, I'm super anxious.
That sounds like a mix of excitement and pressure. What about this opportunity is making you feel anxious?
client: I think it's the pressure to live up to my own expectations and the fear of failing. Like, what if I can't hack it or if it’s not as perfect as I imagined?

Balancing such high hopes can be daunting, especially when self-expectations come into play. It's understandable to feel anxious when so much is on the line. What does success in this opportunity look like to you, and where do these expectations stem from?

I guess success would mean doing really well in the role and proving to myself that I belong there. But I think these expectations might come from my own need to validate all the hard work and sacrifices I've made to get here. It's like, I want to show that it was all worth it.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their feelings of anxiety and the pressure stemming from self-expectations, providing a detailed context of their thoughts and emotions regarding the new opportunity. Empathy and rapport have been built as the therapist validated the client's feelings and explored the client's definition of success and its origins. It seems the client is ready to explore motivations for change and engage in change talk. The Exploring phase objectives have been met. The therapist effectively used reflections and open-ended questions to draw out the client's story, establishing a solid foundation for the Guiding phase.

dialogue.statement: It's natural to seek validation for your hard work, and wanting to prove that your efforts have been worthwhile is understandable. How do you imagine your life might change if you embraced this opportunity without the weight of perfection?

client(guiding): If I could just go into it without stressing over being perfect, maybe I'd actually enjoy the experience more. I'd probably feel more open to learning and making mistakes without feeling like they're the end of the world.

Letting go of the pursuit of perfection seems to open up space for growth and enjoyment. What are some small steps you could take to start embracing this opportunity with more openness and less pressure?

Maybe I could start by reminding myself that it’s okay to make mistakes and that they’re part of the learning process. I guess setting realistic goals instead of aiming for perfection might help, and maybe even talking to others who have been through similar experiences to get their perspective.

Acknowledging that mistakes are a natural part of learning is a great mindset shift. How might setting realistic goals and seeking out others' experiences enhance your confidence in navigating this opportunity?

I think setting realistic goals could help me stay grounded and keep things in perspective, so I don’t feel overwhelmed by trying to do everything perfectly. Talking to others who've been in similar situations might offer reassurance and help me feel less alone in this, like learning from their experiences and seeing that it's okay not to have it all figured out right away.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear discrepancy between their goal of enjoying the opportunity and their current anxiety-driven behavior. They have explored life with and without the pressure for perfection, expressed Change Talk by suggesting steps like setting realistic goals, and shown decreased ambivalence by focusing on growth and reassurance. The client has implied a readiness to move forward with specific steps, indicating they're ready to develop action plans. OARS feedback: The use of open-ended questions effectively elicited the client's perspective, and reflections helped them identify practical steps forward, suggesting a readiness to advance.

dialogue.statement: Considering what we've discussed, creating an action plan seems like a valuable next step. Possible options could include setting a few specific, realistic goals for yourself in this new role and reaching out to at least one or two individuals with similar experiences to gain insight and support. How do these options feel for you, and are there any other steps you might want to include in your plan?

Those options sound really helpful, actually. Setting goals could give me some direction and reaching out to others seems comforting. I might also try journaling to process my thoughts and feelings along the way. That could help me keep track of my progress and remind me of why I wanted this in the first place.

Journaling is an excellent addition to your plan; it can really help you reflect and stay connected with your motivations. So, setting specific goals for yourself, reaching out to others for insights, and keeping a journal are steps you're considering. What potential challenges do you foresee with these actions, and how might you address them?

client(choosing): I guess one challenge might be procrastination or feeling too anxious to actually reach out to people. I sometimes worry about bothering them or not knowing what to say. With journaling, I might struggle with consistency, especially if things get busy. Maybe setting a schedule or reminders could help with that.

Scheduling reminders is a smart way to stay consistent with journaling, especially during busy times. To address feeling anxious about reaching out, how about preparing a few questions or topics in advance to guide those conversations? This might ease some of the pressure of not knowing what to say. Which of these steps do you feel ready to start with, and how can we monitor your progress together?

client(choosing): Preparing some questions beforehand sounds like a great idea. I think that would make reaching out feel less daunting. I feel ready to start with setting some goals and maybe drafting an email or message template to get the conversations started. As for monitoring progress, maybe I could share updates with you during our sessions, and if I stick to my journaling, I could bring some insights from that too.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan that includes setting specific goals, reaching out to peers, and journaling to navigate their new role without the burden of perfection. Challenges such as procrastination and anxiety have been identified, with strategies like scheduling reminders and preparing conversation topics in place. The client shows readiness by expressing commitment through drafting messages and sharing updates during sessions. Confidence is evident in their proactive approach. To refine the plan, focus on maintaining consistency and addressing any lingering uncertainties. Great progress has been made in aligning their actions with their motivations and addressing barriers.

dialogue.statement: That sounds like a solid plan. Starting with setting your goals and drafting a message template for reaching out can really set you on a positive path. Sharing your progress with me during our sessions will help us celebrate your achievements and tackle any roadblocks together. Bringing insights from your journaling is a wonderful way to deepen our discussions and keep focused on your personal growth. Remember, every step forward counts, and you're doing an amazing job taking charge of this opportunity. Keep being kind to yourself, and trust in the process. Looking forward to hearing how it all unfolds for you!

Thanks, I really appreciate that. I'll definitely give it a go and see how things progress. I'll keep you updated on how it goes and bring in what I can from my journaling. Thanks for all the support!

statement.reasoning: The session effectively summarized goals, coping strategies, and established a next-step plan with client engagement and readiness to progress. OARS feedback: Reflective listening and affirmations helped solidify the client's confidence in their plan.

concern:
title: I just got the postdoc of my dreams so why am I panicking?
Pretty much the title. After several months of working on applications and convincing myself that I was not going to get any offers and this was the end of my academic career, last week I got my dream offer at my dream institution, the place I've wanted to go for years. So why am I terrified instead of excited? I thought this would mean I could finally breathe, but if anything my anxiety is worse. Does anyone else relate to this and if so, how did you address it?
